description: This is the title page of the Hip-Hop Time Capsule book. It features the main title 'HIP-HOP TIME CAPSULE:' in large, bold pink/magenta letters at the top. Below that is the subtitle 'DOCUMENT YOUR PERSONAL JOURNEY' in blue text with spaced lettering. At the bottom, it displays 'AUTHORED BY:' followed by the two authors' names 'ANITA SCIPIO' and 'HILTON V. SCIPIO' in black text. The page uses a clean, modern design with a white background and contrasting typography.
This is a blank page with only the page number '2' centered at the bottom. It appears to be an intentionally blank page, possibly serving as a separator or buffer page in the book's layout.

A thank you page featuring a centered message "Your Support Is Everything!" in purple/blue text at the top with musical note decorations on both sides. Below is "Thank you!" in magenta/pink text, followed by "Anita Scipio and DJ SCIPIO" in black text. The bottom of the page features three silhouette graphics: a breakdancer on the left, a cassette tape in the center, and a standing dancer on the right, all in purple. There's a decorative line divider between the title and thank you message. Page number 3 appears at the bottom center.
Copyright page containing standard rights reservation language and attribution to 2024 Team Scipio. The page features centered text with a copyright symbol and splash icon decoration at the bottom.

This is the Table of Contents page (page 5) of the Hip-Hop Time Capsule book. It features a bold purple title 'TABLE OF CONTENTS' at the top with an underline. The left side has two vertical magenta/pink decorative bars. The contents are listed in 16 numbered entries showing chapter titles and their corresponding page numbers, ranging from page 1 to page 214. The book includes sections on personal journeys, dedications, hip-hop quotes, trivia questions, and personal stories from DJ Scipio and Anita Scipio.

Table of Contents page showing chapters 17-30 of the book. Features a blue underlined 'TABLE OF CONTENTS' header in uppercase. Two vertical magenta/pink bars appear on the left side as a design element. The entries list various topics including interviews with Angela Yee and The Breakfast Club, shout-outs, author information, celebrity photos, and personal messages. A footnote at the bottom explains the automatic numbering system used.

This is the foreword page of the Hip-Hop Time Capsule book. It features a decorative title 'Foreward' at the top with purple text and pink arrow design elements with a diamond center. The page contains three paragraphs explaining the purpose and context of the book. The first paragraph describes Hip-Hop as a living cultural testament. The second paragraph introduces the book and its co-authors Anita Scipio and DJ SCIPIO (Hilton V. Scipio), highlighting DJ SCIPIO's 45+ years of experience in the Hip-Hop industry in The Carolinas. The third paragraph discusses how Hip-Hop's heartbeat lives through individuals like Anita Scipio and her nearly two decades of work at iHeartMedia connecting with Hip-Hop and Rap artists. The page number 7 appears at the bottom.

This page contains a closing statement from an author about personal Hip-Hop experiences, followed by the signature 'In Solidarity, Kool Moe Dee'. Below that is a note from the authors describing the historic 1981 battle between Kool Moe Dee and Busy Bee Starski at Harlem World, which is credited as the first aggressive MC battle in Hip-Hop history. The page includes three QR codes at the bottom that link to recordings of this historic battle.

This is page 13 of the foreword or introduction section of the Hip-Hop Time Capsule book. The author discusses their motivation for creating this unique hybrid journal/book and explains their collaboration with co-author DJ SCIPIO. The text emphasizes that this is a passion project created by a fan rather than an expert, and highlights DJ SCIPIO's 45 years of music industry experience and deep knowledge of Hip-Hop history, including pioneers like DJ Hollywood, Grandmaster Flowers, Disco King Mario, and Cool Herc. The author mentions learning about Hip-Hop's roots in gang culture (particularly the Black Spades in the Bronx) and its musical influences from jazz, funk, and soul. The page concludes by stating that together they created 100 thought-provoking questions and that this journal/book is unique in the market. The page number 13 appears at the bottom center.

This is a foreword or introduction page from a Hip-Hop book. The author describes the challenging process of creating the book covering 50 years of Hip-Hop history. They mention including 50 quotes from artists and 50 trivia questions. The author discusses various setbacks during production including an illegitimate editor and unreliable collaborators. They acknowledge working with their brother Hilton (DJ SCIPIO) and highlight the innovative inclusion of 235 QR codes throughout the book to link to meaningful songs. The page number 14 appears at the bottom.

This is page 15 of the book, containing explanatory text about the QR code integration feature. The page discusses the innovative use of QR codes to link readers to Hip-Hop songs, the family-friendly approach, copyright considerations, and how this feature supports artists while creating an interactive reading experience. The text is presented in three main paragraphs explaining the rationale and implementation of this feature.

This page contains important disclaimers about content suitability and copyright compliance for QR code linking, followed by an introduction to a new section about the Hip-Hop Time Capsule personal journey feature. The page emphasizes that most songs are not suitable for all audiences (shown in purple text) and explains the legal considerations for linking to official artist content. It then transitions to describing the evolution of the journal/book concept, mentioning it will include prompt questions, trivia, quotes, and personal experiences spanning 18 years.

This page explains why the Hip-Hop Time Capsule book was split into two volumes. The author describes how the project grew beyond its original scope of Hip-Hop fans documenting their personal journeys. The first volume contains stories, pictures, and memories, while the second volume (The Next Chapter) will feature deeper stories about Hip-Hop legends and the iHeart family, with QR codes linking to historical moments. The author gives recognition to Thea Mitchem from iHeartMedia and Power 105.1 New York. The page number 17 appears at the bottom.

This is a 'Sneak Peek' page (page 19) that previews celebrity encounters featured in the book. The page serves as a teaser for the celebrity encounter stories that will appear later in the book.

Page 20 features a heartfelt story about DaBaby. The page includes two photographs at the top - one black and white photo showing someone in a hoodie, and one color photo showing DaBaby with others. The page title 'DaBaby' appears in purple text with a decorative diamond accent below it. The main text tells a touching story about a retired person who received a surprise call from DaBaby via his label rep Sherri. The story describes how DaBaby was upset when he didn't see this person at The Breakfast Club and reached out to them. The author expresses gratitude and love for DaBaby, Sherri, Garrett and the team. At the bottom is the 'stay TUNED' logo in purple stylized text. The page number 20 appears at the bottom.

This is a dedication page featuring two framed photographs at the top - one showing the author with her daughter, and another showing her with her granddaughter. The page contains a heartfelt dedication message from Anita (Mom & Grandma) to her daughter Arlene Yvette Scipio and granddaughter Gayla Renee Robinson. The text expresses deep love, gratitude, and appreciation for their support, particularly mentioning concerns about proper rest during the book's creation. The dedication is signed 'Love, Mom & Grandma' with decorative pink heart graphics on either side. The page number 21 appears at the bottom.

A heartfelt dedication page titled 'HILTON'S DEDICATION' featuring two framed photographs at the top - one showing a young woman in a yellow dress holding what appears to be a Broadway playbill, and another showing a young girl in a pink 'Birthday Girl' shirt. The dedication is addressed to the author's daughter Cheri Scipio-White, granddaughters Kadence L. White and Chloe N. White, and late son Hilton Fuquan Scipio (RIP). The text expresses love, dedication, and hope that the book will inspire family members to be themselves and follow their hearts while remembering their shared legacy. The page is signed 'With all my love, Dad/Papa Scipio' and includes decorative floral and dove accent images at the bottom corners. Page number 22 appears at the bottom.

description: Page 180 featuring personal stories about gifts from Snoop Dogg (a Baby Powder scented candle from his Broadus Family Collection) and Rick Ross (multiple cases of Belaire and Bumbu Rum). Includes a product image of the Broadus Family Collection candle and four photos showing various bottles and gift boxes of luxury spirits. Question 51 asks about the best advice received from a Hip-Hop legend, with the answer about staying true to oneself. The page has a white/cream background with black text and includes emotional expressions of missing both artists.

This is a content page from a Hip-Hop Time Capsule interview book featuring two questions (52 and 53). Question 52 asks about humorous stories involving favorite artists and includes a detailed anecdote about DMX on his birthday, describing how he came in for an interview while celebrating, asked for prayers, and later was seen buying hotdogs for everyone near a neighborhood hotdog stand in his characteristic raspy voice. Question 53 addresses the role of women in early Hip-Hop and their contributions to the genre through themes of feminism, gender equality, and social justice. The page includes a large magenta circular badge with '52' and the footer shows '@ANITA' and page number 181.

This page continues from previous content and includes Fun Fact #53 about two sisters who created 'Somebody Say Ho' and worked with Grandmaster Flash and The Furious Five. Features a personal story about meeting Lil Debbie through Van Silk. Contains two photos: one selfie with Lil Debbie and one of a building where Grandmaster Flash lived. Includes a QR code for a video about the origin of 'Somebody Say Ho.' Questions 54 and 55 ask about favorite and 'baddest' women artists in Hip-Hop and R&B, with answer 54 listing Queen Latifah, Salt-N-Pepa, MC Lyte, Sha-Rock, Roxanne Shante, Lauryn Hill, Missy Elliott, Eve, TLC and Remy Ma.

Blige, Beyonce, Lauryn Hill, and Faith Evans, with QR codes linking to their songs. Question 56 asks about favorite male Hip-Hop and R&B artists, with an extensive list including Will Smith, Snoop Dogg, Tupac, LL Cool J, and many others, ending with a tribute to deceased legends. The page number 55 appears in a pink circle at the top right, and 56 in a pink circle on the left side.

The page features five QR codes at the top linking to classic hip-hop songs including 'Ice Ice Baby' by Vanilla Ice, 'Doo Wop' by DaBaby, 'Jump Around' by House of Pain, 'Look Back At It' by A Boogie Wit The Hoodie, and '3rd Bass-Brooklyn-Queens'. The question asks whether the respondent chose a career in rap or hip-hop and how they're contributing, or what they're doing instead. The answer section contains a detailed response from someone named Anita who worked as a receptionist at iHeartMedia in NYC, including Power 105.1, where she met numerous music legends over her 35-year radio career. A pink splash accent appears on the right side with the number 57.

Page 185 continues a narrative about meeting country music legends (Dolly Parton, Emmy Lou Harris, George Jones, Willie Nelson, Randy Travis, Garth Brooks, Waylon Jennings) and working at WPLJ-FM. Question 58 asks about challenges faced in a Hip-Hop career, with a detailed answer about staying calm around Hip-Hop legends while working at iHeartMedia for twenty years. Question 59 asks about supportive family members or friends. A large decorative microphone icon with the number '58' appears on the left side of the answer text.

Page 186 describes the author's retirement from iHeartMedia and the elaborate retirement party organized by colleagues and friends. The page details the committee members who organized the event, including executives like Thea Mitchem, Tom Cuddy, Scott Hopeck, Jim Kerr, and Elvis Duran. It lists other party planners including Danielle Delillo, Nicole Wendel, Jamie Megargee, and others. The author expresses gratitude for the love and support received over 35 years, noting how her granddaughter Gayla witnessed this appreciation. A reference is made to 'Hip-Hop Time Capsule: The Next Chapter' where pictures from the party will be shared. The page ends with question 60 about overcoming challenges. A magenta/pink circular badge with '59' appears on the right side of the page.

inputFields.label: 71. Who are (or were) your favorite West Coast artists?
72. Do you believe that Hip-Hop has promoted positive change in the world? If so, how?

description: Page 194 contains two Hip-Hop questions with example answers and QR codes. Question 71 asks about favorite West Coast artists, with an example answer listing Tupac, Snoop Dogg, Ice Cube, Dr. Dre, and others including Kendrick Lamar. Four QR codes are displayed with song titles underneath: 'No Limit' by G-Eazy, 'Colors' by Ice Tea, 'The Next Episode' by Dr. Dre ft. Snoop Dogg, and 'Straight Outta Compton' by N.W.A. Question 72 asks if Hip-Hop has promoted positive change in the world, with an example answer affirming it has through cultural expression, social commentary, community empowerment, fashion, and economic impact. The page is credited to @ANITA at the bottom.

This is a response page showing answers to questions 73 and 74 about artists who have positively and negatively impacted Hip-Hop. Question 73's answer is displayed in a light gray rounded box with the number '73' in a magenta circle on the right. The respondent lists Common, Kendrick Lamar, J. Cole, Drake, and Big Sean as positive influences. Below are four QR codes linking to specific songs by these artists. Question 74's answer appears in another light gray box with '74' in a magenta circle on the left, discussing Drill Music as over-hyped while acknowledging exceptions from Chicago artists like Polo G, G Herbo, and others. Five QR codes are shown below linking to songs by these artists. The page includes song titles with artist names beneath each QR code, and is attributed to 'ANITA' at the bottom.

Page 196 features question 75 about Hip-Hop songs that match energy during frustrating times. The page includes promotional content for Prince Dre with a crown icon, multiple QR codes linking to his book 'Surviving O Block: The Streets Don't Love You', Instagram, and various song references. There's a testimonial quote from Anita Scipio endorsing Prince Dre's book. The answer lists specific songs including 'Everything Tonight' by Pitbull ft. Ne-Yo, 'How Ya like Me Now' by Kool Moe Dee, 'They Don't Give A F*** About Us' by Tupac, and 'Now That We Found Love' by Heavy D & The Boyz. Nine QR codes are displayed throughout the page linking to various resources and songs mentioned.

Page 76 asks about local/state artists and DJs who contributed to Hip-Hop. The answer lists numerous artists from New York state. The page features a detailed spotlight on Ed Lover, his role as MTV Yo! MTV Raps co-host, and his contribution to bringing Hip-Hop to mainstream television. The number 76 appears in a pink circle. Three QR codes at the bottom link to Ed Lover content: his signature dance, a Breakfast Club interview, and his Expert Opinion show.

A tribute page dedicated to Ed Lover, written by Anita Scipio. The page contains a heartfelt testimonial about working with Ed Lover at Power 105.1 and attending his comedy shows at Carolines Comedy Club. It includes two photographs: one from about sixteen years ago showing Dana, Ed Lover, and Anita, and another more recent photo. The page notes that Ed is currently hosting The Ed Lover Experience on 94.7 The Block (WXBK-FM) in New York, Monday through Friday from 7pm-10pm. Page number 198 appears at the bottom.

Page 199 contains questions 77 and 78 with pre-filled answers. Question 77 asks about favorite beatbox artists, with the answer naming Doug E. Fresh, Biz Markie, and The Fat Boys, accompanied by three QR codes for music samples. A definition of beatboxing is provided. Question 77 appears in a circular magenta badge. Question 78 asks about the most sampled artist, with the answer identifying James Brown and providing definitions of sampling and historical context. Question 78 also appears in a circular magenta badge. The page has a clean, educational layout with definitions marked by asterisks.

inputFields.label: What rapper, if any, influenced you to become, or want to become, a rapper? How?
Like Mt. Rushmore, if there were a Mt. EASTmore of Hip-Hop, who would you choose?

description: Page 200 contains two questions (79 and 80) with pre-filled example answers displayed in rounded rectangular text boxes. Question 79 asks about rapper influences with a negative response shown. Question 80 asks about creating a Mt. Rushmore of East Coast Hip-Hop, with an answer listing LL Cool J, DMX, Jay Z, and Biggie, noting that LL Cool J and DMX selections appear elsewhere. At the bottom are four QR codes linking to classic hip-hop songs by Jay-Z and The Notorious B.I.G. The page uses pink circular number badges (79 and 80) to mark each question.

Page 201 displays two completed questions about Mt. Rushmore-style Hip-Hop monuments. Question 81 asks about a Mt. WESTmore of Hip-Hop, answered with Tupac, Snoop Dogg, Ice Cube, and Dr. Dre. Four QR codes link to related songs. Question 82 asks about a Mt. Ladies-Onlymore of Hip-Hop, answered with Queen Latifah, Salt-N-Pepa, and Missy Elliot, with three QR codes linking to their songs. The answers are presented in speech bubble-style callouts with circular numbered badges (81 and 82 in magenta).

Page 202 features Question 83 asking about local DJs who made the biggest impact on Hip-Hop. The response includes a comprehensive list of influential New York-based DJs including Grandmaster Flash, Ed Lover, DJ Marley Marl, DJ Clark Kent, and others. The author then shares a personal tribute to DJ Kut, describing their friendship during their time at Power 105.1 and DJ Kut's exceptional showmanship at Caroline's Comedy Club. The page includes a circular pink badge with '83' in white, a handwritten-style signature reading 'Love ya Buddy! - Anita', and a quote from DJ Kut: 'Health is Wealth.' The page number 202 appears at the bottom.

Page 203 features two questions (84 and 85) with their answers. Question 84 asks about favorite DJ songs at a club, answered with 'I was a never a DJ.' Question 85 asks about the first official Hip-Hop love song, answered with detailed information about LL Cool J's 'I Need Love' from 1987. The answer includes extensive fun fact research explaining the historical significance of the song as a groundbreaking moment in Hip-Hop that introduced vulnerability and romance to the genre. The page includes two pink circular badges with numbers 84 and 85, a QR code at the bottom linking to 'I Need Love', and the page number 203 with '@ANITA' credit at the bottom.

Page 204 features two questions with answers. Question 86 asks about favorite Hip-Hop love songs, with a brief response stating there are none. Question 87 asks about favorite women artists in Hip-Hop, with a detailed answer naming Sha-Rock, Roxanne Shante, Angie Stone, Cardi B, Young M.A, and GloRilla. An extensive footnote provides historical context about Angie Stone's contribution to Hip-Hop through The Sequence, including their pioneering role as one of the first female rap groups and their 1979 hit 'Funk You Up.' The note ends with a tribute acknowledging Angie Stone's passing on March 1, 2025. At the bottom are four QR codes linking to songs by the mentioned contemporary artists. A thank you note credits DJ SCIPIO for sharing insight about Angie Stone.

Page 205 contains questions 88 and 89 about music playlists and graffiti artists. Question 88 asks what's on the person's playlist, with an answer listing several hip-hop songs by Redman, LL Cool J ft. Eminem, DaBaby, and Eminem. Five QR codes are included to access the mentioned songs. A fun fact explains how Power 105.1 introduced them to 'I Am Blessed', the only song they don't breakdance to. Question 89 asks about favorite graffiti artists. The answer mentions Blade, a prominent artist on Bronx #2 trains, noting they don't have a current favorite. A definition of graffiti and its connection to Hip-Hop culture in the 1970s-1980s is provided. A breakdancer illustration appears with a boombox.

This is page 206 of a Hip-Hop Time Capsule book featuring two questions about the Drake and Kendrick Lamar beef. Question 90 asks what ignited the legendary beef, with a response in a black circular badge (numbered 90) stating the responder wasn't up on what started it but became engaged when it made headlines. Question 91 asks how it impacted perception, with a response in a pink circular badge (numbered 91) explaining that Kendrick's 'Not Like Us' changed their perception of Drake, though they still enjoy Drake's work, particularly 'Started From The Bottom' and '0 To 100/The Catch Up.' Two QR codes at the bottom link to these Drake songs. The page is credited to @ANITA.

Page 207 displays two answered questions about the Drake vs. Kendrick Lamar diss track battle. Question 92 asks about memorable lyrics from diss tracks, with the response noting that Drake's tracks weren't memorable but highlighting Kendrick's lyrics mentioning Future, 21 Savage, Quavo, and Atlanta history. Question 93 asks who won, with the answer declaring Kendrick Lamar the winner based on 'Not Like Us.' Two QR codes are present linking to 'Family Matters' by Drake and 'Not Like Us' by Kendrick Lamar. The responses are shown in gray boxes with magenta circular number badges (92 and 93). The page footer shows @ANITA.

This page contains two questions (94 and 95) with their corresponding answers. Question 94 asks about whether inner-circle opinions matched the respondent's views, with a short affirmative answer 'Yes, it did!' displayed in a light gray bubble next to a magenta circle with '94'. Question 95 asks about rivalries in Hip-Hop culture, with a longer, detailed response discussing the Drake and Kendrick beef, displayed in a light gray text bubble next to a magenta circle with '95'. The page is numbered 208 with '@ANITA' at the bottom.

This is page 209 of a Hip-Hop Time Capsule book featuring two Q&A entries. Question 96 asks about iconic beefs in Hip-Hop, with a detailed answer listing historic rivalries including Kool Moe Dee vs Busy B, Jay-Z vs Nas, 50 Cent vs Ja Rule, Tupac vs Biggie, and Drake vs Kendrick Lamar. Question 97 asks about breaking news that changed perception of an admired artist, with an answer about Diddy and a hotel video incident. The page includes two large circular magenta numbered badges (96 and 97) positioned on the left and right sides respectively. The footer shows '@ANITA' and page number 209.

Page 210 contains questions 98 and 99 with completed answers. Question 98 asks about artists representing both old-school and new-school Hip-Hop, with a comprehensive list of artists provided including Snoop Dogg, LL Cool J, 50 Cent, Fat Joe, Method Man, Lil Wayne, Maino, Sean Paul, Eminem, Common, Jeezy, Two Chains, Jadakiss, Nas, Fabolous, Nelly, Chuck D and Flava Flav. Question 99 asks about the fan's role in contributing to Hip-Hop culture, with the answer describing contributions through attending concerts, buying CDs, and showing love to Hip-Hop artists and legends. Five QR codes are displayed linking to songs: 'Paradise (Freestyle)' by Fabolous, 'Forgive Me' by Maino, 'Paradise' by Fat Joe/Anitta/DJ Khaled, 'I Might Forgive... But I Don't Forgive' by Jeezy, and 'Hot in Herre' by Nelly. The responses are numbered 98 and 99 in circular magenta badges.

Final question page (100) with a comprehensive answer about attending The Hip-Hop 50 Live event at Yankee Stadium on August 11, 2023. The response describes the realization of being Hip-Hop through experiencing unity, joy, and celebration with tens of thousands of diverse fans celebrating Hip-Hop's 50th anniversary. Features a large magenta circle with '100' and gray text box containing the full narrative response.

A personal narrative page describing the author's experience at a Hip-Hop concert with family members. The page concludes with the revelation 'I AM HIP-HOP!' The author reflects on multiple generations enjoying the music together, their connection to Hip-Hop culture, and memories of family members. The page is labeled as 'Continued...' at the top and includes the author attribution '@ANITA' and page number 212 at the bottom.

The tone is warm, personal, and filled with affection, using terms of endearment like 'Mama' and 'son' throughout.

Page 236 continues Miss Anita's testimonials about former interns/mentees. The Angie Martinez tribute begins at the bottom of the page, thanking her for years of support and remembering beautiful flowers received on Receptionist Day. The page number 238 appears at the bottom.

The page emphasizes the positive role these officers play in the community and in Amari's life specifically.

description: This is a journal entry page from the Hip-Hop Time Capsule book. The page features a vibrant design with a purple and blue graffiti-style background and a large pink torn-paper effect center section. The header reads 'HIP-HOP TIME CAPSULE' in yellow graffiti-style letters, with 'Document Your Personal Journey' in pink beneath it. The main focus is a quote or prompt 'IT'S ALL LOVE' attributed to 'ANITA', displayed in large yellow outlined text in the center of the pink section. The pink area features a subtle starburst pattern. This appears to be a reflection/response page where readers can document their thoughts related to the theme of love in hip-hop culture. Paint splatter decorative elements appear around the edges. Page number 252 appears at the bottom.

This page features the IT'S ALL LOVE YouTube channel promotional content. It includes the YouTube logo and explains the mission to document and preserve Hip-Hop history through artist interviews. The page lists several recommended platforms and shows for Hip-Hop content, including The Breakfast Club, HOT 97, On the Radar Radio, and several popular podcasts. The content emphasizes the importance of preserving authentic Hip-Hop origins and preventing historical distortion. Page number 255 appears at the bottom.

This is a table of contents page listing various hip-hop related media content including podcasts, radio shows, and educational series. The page includes 15 entries featuring prominent hip-hop personalities and platforms such as Drink Champs, Sway Universe, The Joe Budden Podcast, and others. The page number 256 appears at the bottom.

This is a vibrant title page featuring bold yellow graffiti-style text at the top reading 'HIP-HOP TIME CAPSULE' against a purple background with blue and pink splatter effects. Below that is white text stating 'Document Your Personal Journey'. The center features a large pink burst or explosion shape with a lighter pink starburst pattern inside it. Within this shape, the text 'ANITA' and '"SHARIN' THE LOVE"' appears in yellow graffiti-style lettering. The page number 257 appears at the bottom. The overall design has an urban, hip-hop aesthetic with torn paper edge effects around the central pink shape.

Biography page for DJ COOL KEV featuring a professional photo of him wearing a white 'Total Package' t-shirt and matching blue cap. The page details his career starting in 1989, his influences, education at the Institute of Audio Research, collaborations with major artists, and his extensive mixtape collection. Includes acknowledgment from DJ COOL KEV and STEADY BREEZIN ENT. thanking supporters. Page number 258 appears at bottom.

This is a contact and promotional page (page 259) featuring DJ Cool Kev's email address (coolkev117@aol.com). The page displays the 'TOTAL PACKAGE!!! COLLECTION' brand logo at the top center, which includes various mascot characters like a blue dripping character, yellow lion mascot, Original Bulldogs logo, and Original Young Kings/Queens branding with QR code. Below are two framed photographs showing DJ Cool Kev with children wearing branded merchandise - blue and red t-shirts with 'I' branding and caps. At the bottom are four QR codes linking to Instagram, Website, a newly published article about the Total Package Collection Brand, and the Total Package Brand itself. The page serves as both a contact page and brand showcase for DJ Cool Kev's Total Package Collection merchandise line.

Artist profile page for Mark Borino featuring a professional photo of the producer/artist wearing a brown jacket with black collar, showing his distinctive hairstyle and beard. The page details his major accomplishments including co-producing 'Papi's Home' on Drake's 'Certified Lover Boy' album in 2021, which reached #8 on Billboard's Hot 100 and earned him his first platinum record. The text highlights his Harold Adamson Lyric Award from ASCAP, his independent label 'House of Rivero', and mentions his recent releases 'Don't Wait Up' and 'Visions'. Two QR codes are present - one for Instagram (bottom left) and one for ffm.bio (bottom right). Page number 260 appears at the bottom.

Profile page for Jamie Lynn, creator of Bark Avenue Treats organic dog treats. The page features a professional photo of Jamie Lynn with long blonde hair on the left side, and her business logo showing a cartoon dog with a butterfly on the right side. The page details her 21-year career in NYC radio as an executive morning show producer for Lite FM, and her passion for creating handmade, healthy, organic dog treats with pure ingredients. Two QR codes are included at the bottom - one for @BARKAVENUETREATS and one for Instagram. The page uses purple and pink gradient header design with a decorative diamond divider.

This is a testimonial/acknowledgment page dedicated to Adrian Silvestre, Director of Food and Beverage at City Experiences. The page features two VIP badges with gold laurel wreaths and crowns at the top. The main text provides heartfelt recognition of Adrian's career journey from humble beginnings, his role at City Experiences/Hornblower, and the exceptional hospitality he provides on cruises, particularly the New York Bateaux. The page includes the City Experiences logo and two QR codes at the bottom, along with the tagline 'A Night To Remember!!!' Page number 263 appears at the bottom center.

This page tells the success story of Shaw-nae's House, a soul-food restaurant. It features the restaurant's logo at the top (a stylized house with the number 5 and Shaw-nae's HOUSE text). Below are three photos: a chef presenting food, Shaw-nae with another person holding flowers, and a collage of various dishes from the restaurant. The narrative describes how the restaurant owner contacted The Breakfast Club for exposure, leading to success and recognition. At the bottom are five QR codes linking to major media features including New York Times, Elvis Duran, NYC Tourism, Today Show, and NYT's 50 Best Restaurants in America list.

This appears to be a blank or nearly blank page with only the page number 265 visible in the bottom right corner. The page has a white/off-white background with no other visible content, text, images, or decorative elements.

This is a title page for the Hip-Hop Time Capsule book featuring DJ Scipio's 'Thank-You'. The design has a vibrant purple and blue background with graffiti-style yellow text for the main title at the top. The subtitle 'Document Your Personal Journey' appears in white and pink. The center features a large pink burst/star shape with torn paper edges containing the artist name 'DJ SCIPIO' and track title 'THANK-YOU' in bold yellow outlined letters. The page number 266 appears at the bottom. The overall aesthetic is colorful and energetic, matching hip-hop culture's visual style.

This is a dedication page featuring two tribute messages to DJ NUFIYO. The page has a decorative title in graffiti-style purple lettering at the top. The first section is dedicated to Shirley Williams and includes purple floral watercolor decorations. The second section is dedicated to Greg Simpkins and includes a photograph showing two men in a handshake pose - one wearing sunglasses and a pinstriped suit, the other in casual black clothing. Both messages express gratitude and appreciation for long-term friendship and support.

This is a title page for a section called 'DJ Scipio Shout-Outs' within the Hip-Hop Time Capsule book. The page features vibrant purple and pink colors with a graffiti-style header 'HIP-HOP TIME CAPSULE' in yellow 3D letters at the top. Below that is a pink banner with white text reading 'Document Your Personal Journey'. The center of the page displays a pink torn-paper or starburst effect containing the text 'DJ SCIPIO "SHOUT-OUTS"' in bold yellow outlined letters. The design includes paint splatter accents and has an urban, street art aesthetic. The page number 268 appears at the bottom.

A heartfelt acknowledgments page titled 'DJ SHOUT-OUT' with three paragraphs expressing gratitude. The first thanks the author's family for their love and support. The second gives special recognition to sister Anita for her crucial role in making the book happen. The third thanks the broader Hip-Hop community including DJs, MCs, producers, and labels. The page is decorated with a purple brushstroke banner at the top and three music-themed icons (vinyl records and DJ headphones) at the bottom.

Page 270 is a thank you and shout-out page dedicated to the Carolinas. DJ SCIPIO expresses gratitude to fans for 45 years of support, stating 'without you, there would be no DJ SCIPIO!' The page features both South Carolina and North Carolina state flags. A special shout-out is given to The Breakfast Club/Power 105.1 radio show, specifically mentioning Jess Hilarious and Loren LaRosa. The thank you section lists several prominent hip-hop media personalities including Charlamagne Tha God (from Moncks Corner, SC), DJ Envy, Angela Yee (host of Way Up With Angela Yee), Jim Kerr, Kelly Kramer, DJ Clue, DJ Prostyle, DJ Suss One, and Angie Martinez. The page concludes with a special shout-out to Mikey Truth, described as 'South Carolina's #1 Urban Blogger and Queen of Paperwork,' accompanied by a crown logo with the text 'QUEEN OF PAPERWORK.'

This is a dedication and acknowledgments page from DJ Scipio. It features a purple graffiti-style header reading 'DJ SCIPIO' and a purple brush stroke banner containing 'SHOUT-OUT' in white text. The page contains personal dedications to family members including his sister Deborah Scipio, nieces Shirley Leslie Smith and Denise Scipio, and nephews DJ Cool Kev and Melvin T. Hayes. It includes a special acknowledgment to childhood friend Kool Moe Dee for writing the book's foreword. The remainder lists numerous individuals from the hip-hop and music industry community including DJs, record pool operators, and other music professionals. The page number 271 appears at the bottom.

Page 272 features a 'DJ Shout-Out' section with a purple painted brush stroke banner containing the white text 'SHOUT-OUT'. The title 'DJ NOTHIN' appears above in stylized graffiti-style text. The page lists approximately 39 names of DJs, family members, and entertainment industry professionals being acknowledged, arranged in multiple lines across the page. This appears to be an acknowledgments or thank you page recognizing DJs and others who contributed to or supported the project.

This is an 'About the Author' page featuring DJ SCIPIO (Hilton V. Scipio). The page includes a large photograph of DJ SCIPIO in a professional setting, wearing a red vest over a white shirt, positioned at DJ turntables and mixing equipment. The page header has decorative elements with a diamond shape between two horizontal lines. The text provides biographical information about the author's background in Harlem and The Bronx, his musical influences from soul artists, and his early involvement in Hip-Hop culture starting in 1973. This page contains biographical information about DJ SCIPIO, detailing his early influences in New York (including Kool Herc, GrandMaster Flash, Grand Wizard Theodore, and family members), his move to South Carolina in 1989, and his subsequent success in the Dirty South music scene. The text describes his achievements including being among the first to bring Dirty South mixtapes to NYC, receiving over twenty awards including five consecutive Mixtape DJ of the Year awards in South Carolina, and his continued influence in the entertainment and music industry. Page number 275 appears at the bottom.

About the Author page featuring Anita Scipio, former receptionist for iHeartMedia in New York. The page includes a professional photograph of Anita Scipio wearing a black outfit with a pearl necklace, smiling warmly against an orange iHeartMedia branded background. The text describes her nearly two-decade career at iHeartMedia and how she became an iconic figure known affectionately as 'Miss Anita' or 'Mama' to those who worked at the company. The page explains how she transcended her receptionist role to become the face and soul of iHeartMedia, witnessing the evolution of the entertainment industry.

This page is a tribute to Anita Scipio, describing her role at iHeartMedia's New York office. The text highlights her nurturing personality, her relationships with celebrities and colleagues who called her 'Mama', and her role as a beacon of support beyond administrative duties. It also mentions her work as an ordained minister for over twenty years and her charitable endeavors. The page number 277 appears at the bottom.

This page showcases media interview appearances with two prominent radio shows. The top section features The Breakfast Club interview with a group photo in their studio setting, including The Breakfast Club logo and a QR code for accessing the interview. The bottom section highlights an interview on Way Up with Angela Yee, showing the host with a guest in the iHeartRADIO studio, along with the Way Up logo and another QR code. The page number 278 appears at the bottom. This appears to be documentation of promotional media appearances related to the Hip-Hop Time Capsule project.

This is a tribute/memorial page featuring 9 photographs showing the same woman (likely the book's author or subject) posing with various famous hip-hop artists. The page is titled 'Thank you all, for the love and great memories...' at the top. The photos are arranged in a 3x3 grid, each labeled with the artist's name: Kool Moe Dee, LL Cool J, Ice-T (top row), DMX, Snoop Dogg, Rick Ross (middle row), and 2 Chainz, Fat Joe, and Treach (bottom row). Each photo shows a warm, friendly moment between the woman and the respective artist. The page number 279 appears at the bottom center.

This page displays a 3x3 grid of photographs featuring the same woman posing with various hip-hop celebrities and artists. The top row shows photos with Mary J Blige, Kid 'n Play, and Ice Cube. The middle row features Redman, Meek Mill, and Moneybagg Yo. The bottom row includes Rev Run, DMC, and A$AP Rocky. Each photo is labeled with the celebrity's name beneath it. This appears to be a personal collection showcasing meetings with prominent figures in hip-hop culture. The page number 280 appears at the bottom.

A media collage page showcasing Will Smith's viral moment from January 2020. The page features a decorative title with ornamental arrows and a gold shield icon, followed by multiple screenshots of news coverage from various outlets. The images show Will Smith embracing and celebrating with Anita Scipio, a retiring iHeartRadio receptionist, at her farewell party. A QR code is included in the upper right for additional content. The layout displays approximately 10-12 screenshots from different media sources, all documenting this heartwarming celebrity encounter that generated widespread press coverage.

This page features a personal reflection from Anita about her retirement and Hip-Hop journey. At the top are two QR codes - one labeled 'Will Smith' on the left and one labeled 'Reflecting on My Viral Moment with Will Smith' on the right. In the center is an Instagram-style post showing a photo of two people in conversation. Below is a handwritten-style paragraph expressing gratitude for encounters with Hip-Hop legends and mentioning a future book called 'Hip-Hop Time Capsule: The Next Chapter.' The page number 284 appears at the bottom.

This page documents Anita's retirement celebration and tribute. It features multiple sections with photos, QR codes, and personal messages. The top section shows appreciation for Elvis Duran with an invitation to Anita's 40th birthday party. The main story headline announces Elvis Duran giving the retiring employee a trip and $10,000. Throughout the page are multiple QR codes linking to different content including an 'Ugly Cry Alert', favorite songs of the night ('Suge' by DaBaby and 'It Takes Two' by Rob Base), shout-outs to DJs, and her signature song 'Lean On Me'. The page includes party photos showing decorations and celebrations, as well as a 'Mama's VIP' sign from iHeartAnita.

Final page of the Hip-Hop Time Capsule book titled 'Heartfelt Wishes'. The page features a purple script title at the top, followed by three paragraphs of heartfelt closing messages to readers. The authors thank readers for their journey, share their personal story of perseverance in creating the book despite setbacks, mention their visions coming true with appearances on The Breakfast Club and Angela Yee's show, and offer inspirational advice. The page concludes with 'BE Fearless' styled in purple decorative script, referencing DJ Envy. Page number 286 appears at the bottom.

Final page of the book featuring a photo of Anita and Hilton together at the top, followed by a request for Amazon reviews. The page includes their warm closing message 'Love and Blessings' and 'Thank You'. At the bottom are four QR codes linking to: Amazon reviews, Anita's Instagram, Team Scipio website, and DJ Scipio's logo showing pyramids with the Smooth Entertainment brand. This serves as both a conclusion and a call-to-action page encouraging reader engagement.
